text: Hi all, is there any new service that is offers some approximation of what JuliaBox did?

elements.text: Hi all, is there any new service that is offers some approximation of what JuliaBox did?

text: Ah, I see. I guess I was looking for something free - I'm a grad student trying to run a demo for my lab. I was hoping I could create an interactive notebook that they could follow along with

elements.text: Ah, I see. I guess I was looking for something free - I'm a grad student trying to run a demo for my lab. I was hoping I could create an interactive notebook that they could follow along with

text: If you don't need a lot of compute power and if you are ok that nothing gets saved, you can use <https://mybinder.org/>

elements.text: If you don't need a lot of compute power and if you are ok that nothing gets saved, you can use

text: You can just point it to a github repo that has an empty `Project.toml` and `Manifest.toml` in it, and then it will spin up a Julia environment.

in it, and then it will spin up a Julia environment.

text: I think medium term <https://github.com/features/codespaces> is going to be an awesome solution, but at the moment that is a beta and there is a waitlist to get in.

text: Just tested binder - perfect for my purposes! Thanks!!

elements.text: Just tested binder - perfect for my purposes! Thanks!!

text: JuliaHub is built atop the old JuliaBox infrastructure… but we ran out of free cloud compute credits and we don’t have a Jupyter “app” yet.  You still get $25 free in your first month, which is good for a decent amount of small compute.

elements.text: JuliaHub is built atop the old JuliaBox infrastructure… but we ran out of free cloud compute credits and we don’t have a Jupyter “app” yet.  You still get $25 free in your first month, which is good for a decent amount of small compute.
